newsitem.title: USA: Confident Clinton campaigns in Virginia, Tennessee.
newsitem.headline: Confident Clinton campaigns in Virginia, Tennessee.

text.p: In a sign of his campaign's confidence, President Bill Clinton on Sunday visited Virginia and Tennessee, states not critical to his re-election, and found time to have dinner with Vice President Al Gore.
The visits, the start of a three-day, seven-state campaign swing, illustrated the Clinton campaign's growing optimism as it races down the final stretch to the Nov. 5 election.

Ahead in all national polls -- the latest Reuters tracking poll gave Clinton a 13.4 percentage point lead over Republican Bob Dole while CNN/USA Today Gallup put it at 20 points -- Clinton appeared to be playing a complex campaign endgame.
On one hand he sought to buttress his commanding position in traditionally crucial Midwestern states like Illinois and Ohio, which he will visit on Monday and Tuesday.

On the other, he wanted to use the campaign's waning days to further objectives beyond his own re-election -- like positioning Gore for a 2000 run at the White House and helping Democratic candidates for Congress.
Appearing with Gore at an evening rally held at Nashville's Vanderbilt University, Clinton had nothing but praise for the vice president.
"We spend so much time together now, it's almost like we can begin to speak in code," Clinton said. "Two or three words and I can finish the sentence, and vice versa."

"There has never been a relationship quite like this in American history between a president and vice president," he added. "It's been one of the most richly rewarding things in my life and I think it's been very good for the American people."
Making his fourth visit to Tennessee since August, Clinton seemed intent on making sure Gore not suffer the embarrassment of losing his home state, or doing poorly there.
There seemed little danger of that, as one recent Tennessee opinion poll gave Clinton a 15 percentage point lead over Dole, but the Clinton-Gore campaign was taking no chances.
Clinton and Gore were later scheduled to have dinner at a Nashville restaurant before the president flew on to St. Louis, where he was to spend the night.
Earlier, in another token of his confidence, Clinton campaigned in Virginia, a state that has not sent a Democrat to the White House since 1964, when it supported Lyndon Johnson.

At an outdoor rally in Springfield, Va, Clinton campaigned with Mark Warner, a Democratic businessman seeking to oust three-term Republican John Warner from the Senate, and joked about the state's long Republican tradition.

"Most people in Virginia have been voting against members of my party for president for over three decades now and I know how hard it is to break a habit," he said. "One of the things we all teach our kids is that some habits have to be broken."
As he has done throughout the campaign, Clinton sought to paint himself as the candidate of the future and, without mentioning him by name, to portray Dole as a man of the past.

"Your fellow Virginians ... did a great thing for America when they and their native sons led us into the 19th Century 200 years ago," he added. "Virginia can help lead America into the 21st Century nine days from now."
Recent polls gave Clinton a six- to nine-point lead over Dole in Virginia, one of the most reliably Republican states over the past three decades.
On Monday Clinton was scheduled to make speeches in St. Louis, Minneapolis and Chicago and on Tuesday in Columbus, Ohio, and Philadelphia.

After a one-night stopover at the White House, Clinton was to begin a seven-day campaign blitz across the country ending in Little Rock, Arkansas, for election night -- near the site where he declared his candidacy in October 1991.
